contents.content: Near-infrared wavelengths of light are not as easily deflected or absorbed by dust, unlike shorter visible wavelengths. The LSST Camera has three filters that can transmit some near infrared light: i, z, and y. Using these filters make it possible to see through some of the gas and dust of a nebula, revealing hidden stars. These filters are also excellent for detecting very faint red stars, which give off more light in near-infrared wavelengths than in visible red light.
You can make color images from near-infrared light by assigning a color to the image taken through an near-infrared filter. Letâ€™s see how this works:

The Trifid Nebula is a dense cloud of gas and dust. The gas in the nebula is the bright cloud, and the dust is where there appear to be very dark areas cutting across the gas. If the Trifid Nebula was observed using visible light alone, many of the stars within it would be hidden from view.

To make a full color image of the Trifid Nebula, each of the filtered images had to be assigned a color, then combined. The g filter image was colorized blue, the r filter image was colorized green, and the z (near-infrared) filter image was colorized red.

images.figText: Images of the Trifid Nebula taken through three different filters. Credit: T.A. Rector, (University of Alaska Anchorage) and CTIO/NOAO/NSF.
The g, r, z filter images of the Trifid Nebula have been assigned colors to produce a final color image on the right.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: Compare the three black and white images of the Trifid Nebula, taken through g, r, and z filters. What differences in the brightness and amount of gas and stars do you notice between the three images?

question.title: Question #1
question.label: What color do the stars that were previously hidden by dust appear to be in the full color image?

question.title: Question #1
question.label: If only infrared filters are used (like the i, z, and y filters), would you be able to determine which stars are the ones hidden by the cloud of gas and dust? Explain your reasoning.
